captions.text:
Thank you once again to our wonderful Patreon 
subscribers for voting for this year&#39;s drought

relief retro review, and extra special thanks 
for snubbing Danganronpa for the third year in a

row. Anime is like the Rice Krispies in 
a Kellogg&#39;s Variety Pack, apparently—you

only go for it when there&#39;s literally fuck 
all else. I don&#39;t hate the idea of playing

Danganronpa or think that I couldn&#39;t possibly 
enjoy it; I just find it increasingly amusing

that it keeps showing up only to get kicked in 
the head. Like my dog when I&#39;m using VR. Anyway,

this year&#39;s winner was Sid Meier&#39;s Pirates!. The 
2004 remake rather than the 1987 original. I mean,

Christ, it&#39;s retro review, not fucking 
paleolithic. Sid Meier is a big fish

from old-school gaming best known for having a 
very unreasonable combination of vowels in his

name and also a pokey little tryhard franchise 
called Civilization. But he was also a man known

to dabble all across the spectrum of management 
games and at one point indulged his unassailable

creativity by making a game about pirates 
called Sid Meier&#39;s Pirates. Then, at some point,

someone stuck an exclamation mark on the end of 
the title, presumably as a marketing exercise.

So now, my job is to let you know how well 
Sid Meier&#39;s PIRATES! holds up from a modern

perspective. Short answer: not terribly. It&#39;s 
very old school in its design focus. I mean,

playing the PC version on GOG, it has to 
be primarily controlled with the fucking

numpad on your keyboard. Even in 2004, that was 
like having to control a helicopter with a pull

chain flush handle. I&#39;m assuming the format is 
recreating the 1987 original fairly closely,

as it evokes an ancient design philosophy you 
can see in games like Civilization 1 or David

Braben&#39;s Elite, where the attitude in play is not 
so much crafting an experience for the player as

it is crafting an environment in which experiences 
could potentially happen, plonking the player in

the middle, and going, &quot;Don&#39;t fucking look at 
me, asshole. This is your show; get dancin&#39;.&quot;

Which is the first strike for me; I very much 
prefer a game to be intrinsically goal-oriented

with appropriate rewards and punishments. 
I still have occasional anxiety dreams that

canter around the voice of a Japanese-accented 
woman saying, &quot;Don&#39;t worry, Mama can fix this.&quot;

Sid Meier&#39;s PILATES! creates for us a simulated 
version of the 18th century Caribbean,

which—even if we spend our entire time with the 
game sitting perfectly still in a corner of the

map trying to get off with a manatee colony—would 
nevertheless bustle with activity as an array of

NPC factions send their ships back and forth 
to inhabit settlements, negotiate trades,

and fight it out over terrain. The first 
thing we do is pick which seagoing power

to initially side with. Naturally, I went with 
the British—BOOOOOO—yeah, yeah; fuck off. Yes,

historically, the British haven&#39;t been much 
of a force for positivity in global affairs,

but this is the Age of Sail, remember, when at 
least they weren&#39;t as bad as the fucking Spanish.

Our protagonist is a gung-ho twink who runs away 
to sea to escape his family&#39;s victimization by an

evil magistrate, but during a grueling voyage, you 
mutiny against an evil captain and successfully

argue to the assembled experienced sailors that 
you should be captain instead. The narration

text scoots around the question of precisely 
how you did that; I&#39;m assuming by having the

tightest buttocks on the entire lower deck. After 
that, we get dumped to a really zoomed-out view

of a boat we control with numpad keys and 
are free to merrily explore the Caribbean.

As long as we&#39;re going west. The wind&#39;s almost 
always pointing that way for realism&#39;s sake,

so going west is a lovely holiday cruise and 
going east is like climbing a spiral staircase

on a pogo stick. But never mind that; my first 
act was to rock up at a British settlement where

I bolstered my crew (read: health bar) by raking 
some dudes off the floor of the tavern and then

visited the governor, who told he&#39;s super 
cool with the whole mutiny thing as long

as I go murder some Spaniards. Then, I explored 
a bit more and found a French settlement where

the governor was all like &quot;Zut alors! You&#39;re 
now a captain in the French Navy because you

murdered a Spaniard on the way here, which 
is literally the only qualification.&quot; Then,

I found a Dutch settlement where the 
governor went, &quot;Windmills and tulips, etc.,

please murder Spaniards.&quot; Then, I had to stop at 
a Spanish settlement, where the governor said,

&quot;We&#39;re very unhappy you murdered some Spaniards. 
But you did also murder some neutral pirates,

so here&#39;s a captaincy in the Spanish Navy and 
a mansion and please kiss my ugly daughter.&quot; I

was a little perplexed how every time I talked to 
a governor, he&#39;d bring his fucking daughter out,

all with ratings for beauty apparently 
decided by how much tit they&#39;re showing off.

And I&#39;d be expected to dance with them 
in a slightly humiliating minigame

about trying to remember which movements 
correspond to which hand gestures. Sorry,

did I come in the wrong door? Am I playing Sid 
Meier&#39;s Debutantes? I made a conscious decision

to stop indulging the fucking governor&#39;s daughter 
nonsense, although it wasn&#39;t easy &#39;cause I&#39;d go to

the tavern for rumors of treasure, and all they&#39;d 
have is, &quot;Hey, I hear the Governor of St. Kitts&#39;

daughter shows off 12 centimeters of cleavage!&quot; 
If Sid Meier&#39;s Pie Plates! was being sold today,

they&#39;d probably call it a Roguelike &#39;cause where 
the quests&#39;ll take you and the fatness of each

daughter&#39;s titties is up to RNGesus. You craft 
the experience you want to have, which ultimately

comes down to which of the game&#39;s many largely 
unrelated minigames you can tolerate. I hate the

dancing. Ship combat&#39;s alright. Sword combat&#39;s 
about pressing the right button in response to

the enemy, so it&#39;s basically just the dancing 
again but more on theme. Treasure hunting based

on vague maps is a fun enough exercise. Sneaking 
through a hostile town is about as fun as doing a

cereal box maze puzzle with all your fingers 
stuck in Smarties tubes, and the turn-based

strategy town assaulting minigame seemed 
functional enough the entire one time I did it.

The problem with Sid Meier&#39;s Pratfalls! 
is that it&#39;s taken the individual

elements of a swashbuckling pirate adventure 
story—pirating, treasure hunt, shag rebellious,

posh crumpet—and tried to turn each one into 
a repeating system. Even the long-term goal of

rescuing your family is like that. You defeat the 
evil Baron Twatstache and he reveals the location

of your long-lost sister, so you go rescue her 
with a variant on the treasure-hunting minigame,

and seconds after the tearful reunion, the game 
goes, &quot;Whoops! Now Baron Twatstache knows the

location of your long-lost cat! Better defeat him 
again!&quot; So, even what passes for the plot becomes

grinding out minigames. I wouldn&#39;t say Sid Meier&#39;s 
Perverts! does hold up. In the end, what made me

pack it in was I just couldn&#39;t figure out how 
to keep my crew&#39;s morale up. I&#39;d stay supplied,

I&#39;d pillage ships, find treasure, NOT pillage 
ships, dock at that one place near the Florida

Keys where the barmaid has the really stonking 
baps. Still, the happy face icon slid inexorably

into sad. And eventually, I decided I&#39;d had enough 
of trying to appease these nagging dipshits. I get

enough of this at home when I&#39;ve been playing VR 
too much and the dog&#39;s run out of face medicine.
